review: I rely heavily on this as I only use my iPad to broadcast netflix to my TV. There are all sorts of minor glitches, having to close and reopen the program, completely shutting down and turning back on at times, falls off the wifi network...etcOnly Youtube and Netflix work on it.But when it works its great.
author: J. Baker

review: I bought this primarily to stream Netflix to a Samsung 22" 1080p TV which is on my kitchen counter. Since I already have Netflix I had it up and running in a few minutes. The picture quality is outstanding. What's more you can stream any web page to the TV by clicking the "cast" button at the top right corner of the page. I cast the last episode of Borgen which was streaming on PBS. It worked perfectly.

author: Terry Leyba

review: If you have problems, Google support will be quick to remind you this is a Beta product.  What they don't make clear, is that you are their Beta tester and will be forced to suffer through their learning curve.The product specs state... "Supports Netflix, YouTube, HBO GO, Hulu Plus, Pandora, and Google Play Movies and Music mobile apps as well as select content through Chrome browser."This is a flat out lie. This product only works for sites that provide the Chromecast plug in via their app, and there are very few of them.  Really, Netflix, YouTube and HuluPlus are about the only useful ones.  If you want to watch anything else via the Chrome browser, you can't.  It simply doesn't work.  Amazon Instant Video is blocked.  And if you try to cast anything from your Chrome browser, such as Hulu, it will freeze up and is not watchable.Save yourself the grief.  Spend a few dollars more and get the Roku.
author: Dusty

review: The Chromecast was Google's first opportunity to really hit apple and Microsoft where it hurt. I believe that the expectations far exceeded the delivery. I originally had planned to turn my whole life around converting my entire household into a Google environment. I got of course the Chromecast, and Chromebook to start. Little did I know that the only Chromebook that supports Chromecasting was the Pixel. Literally the most disappointing thing that Google could possibly do to me.. So I dropped it all and went Microsoft. Now that I've invested in one, I'm not really disappointed. But I seriously doubt Google can contend if it doesn't sort out its own compatibility issues first.
author: Price John Monroe
